title-group.article-title: Increased Leisure-Time Physical Activity is Associated With Lower Prevalence of the Metabolic Syndrome in 64-Year Old Women With Impaired Glucose Tolerance

article-meta.aff: 1The Wallenberg Laboratory at Sahlgrenska Center for Cardiovascular and Metabolic Research, The Sahlgrenska University Hospital, Gothenburg, Sweden

author-notes.corresp: Caroline Schmidt, Wallenberg Laboratory for Cardiovaascular Research, Sahlgrenska Academy at University of Gothenburg, S-413 45 Gothenburg, Sweden Email: caroline.schmidt@wlab.gu.se

abstract.p: The metabolic syndrome (MetS) is characterized by a cluster of factors that confer an increased risk of cardiovascular morbidity as well as mortality. It is established that physical activity (PA) has a protective role in cardiovascular morbidity and mortality, mainly through favorable effects on traditional risk factors such as body mass and blood pressure. We assessed the prevalence of MetS in a population-based sample of 64-year-old women with impaired glucose tolerance (IGT) with respect to leisure-time PA (LTPA). The results showed an inverse linear association (P < .05) between LTPA and MetS in this group. In conclusion, this study suggests that an increased PA level has an important role in preventing MetS in women with IGT.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The metabolic syndrome (MetS) describes a cluster of atherosclerotic cardiovascular risk factors that increases the risk of diabetes as well as cardiovascular disease. 1 Essential variables in MetS include visceral obesity, elevated blood pressure (BP), dyslipidemia with elevated triglycerides and low levels of high-density lipoprotein cholesterol (HDL-C), and raised fasting glucose. 2–4 Metabolic syndrome poses a growing worldwide health problem due to the global epidemic of overweight and sedentary lifestyle. 5

Impaired glucose tolerance (IGT) is characterized by increased levels of insulin both when fasting and after a glucose load and shows insulin resistance when investigated with glucose clamp techniques. 6 Impaired glucose tolerance is a risk factor for the development of diabetes and also for cardiovascular disease and mortality in the general population. 7,8 Moreover, epidemiologic observations have shown that IGT is associated with the MetS according to the definition of the National Cholesterol Education Program (NCEP) 9 , in about 50% of individuals. 10

It is well known that physical activity (PA) has a protective role in cardiovascular morbidity and mortality, mainly through its favorable effects on conventional risk factors such as body mass and BP. 11 Studies among different ethnic groups of women have shown inverse dose–response relationships between leisure-time PA (LTPA) and prevalence of the MetS. 2,12

Impaired glucose tolerance has been found to be a risk factor for the development of type 2 diabetes and is also a crucial constituent of the MetS. 7 Therefore, it would be of interest to investigate whether the increased levels of LTPA are associated with lower prevalence of MetS in individuals with diagnosed IGT, the aim being to identify a modifiable risk factor in patients with IGT.
There is a paucity of studies concerning the association between PA and MetS in this high-risk population of women.
Therefore, we performed this study to assess the prevalence of MetS in a population-based sample of 64-year-old women with IGT with respect to LTPA.

sec.title: Study Population
sec.p: The Diabetes, Impaired Glucose Tolerance in Women and Atherosclerosis (DIWA) study was powered to examine subclinical atherosclerosis in the carotid and femoral arteries in a population sample of 64-year-old women living in the Gothenburg region. Briefly, 2602 women identified through the County Register were contacted and screened with a questionnaire. 13 Diabetes, IGT, and normal glucose tolerance (NGT) were defined according to the World Health Organization classification. 14 Diagnosis of IGT was based on 2 OGTTs fulfilling the IGT criteria. Women who had findings corresponding to IGT at the first Oral Glucose Tolerance Test (OGTT) and NGT at the second test were excluded from the present analysis.

Exclusion criteria were unwillingness to participate, recent cancer diagnosis, inflammatory disease, severe mental disorder, other severe illness, or drug addictions. Women who could not understand Swedish were also excluded.

All participants received both written and oral information before they gave their consent to take part in the survey. The protocol was approved by the Ethics Committee at Sahlgrenska University Hospital.

sec.title: Measurements
sec.p: Previously described questionnaires were used to evaluate the history of previous and current disease, smoking habits, and alcohol consumption. 15 Cigarette years was defined as the total number of years of smoking multiplied by the number of cigarettes smoked daily.

A self-administered questionnaire was used to assess the level of LTPA. The screening procedure has been described in detail previously. 16 In brief, body weight, waist, and hip circumference were measured with the participants dressed in underwear. Heart rate and BP was measured twice after a 5-minute supine rest. Venous blood samples were drawn after a fasting period of at least 6 hours. Cholesterol and triglyceride levels were determined by enzymatic techniques (Thermo Fisher Scientific Oy, Vantaa, Finland). High-density lipoprotein cholesterol was determined after precipitation of apoB-containing lipoproteins and low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) was calculated as described by Friedewald et al. 17

The study participants were divided into 3 groups according to their level of LTPA: (1) sedentary lifestyle: spends leisure time mostly reading, watching TV, or other sedentary activities; (2) moderate PA: walking, cycling, or other mild PA such as gardening, fishing, or bowling at least 4 h/week; and (3) hard/competitive PA: running, swimming, tennis, cross-country skiing, or other exercise that leads to sweating several days/week. This questionnaire has been evaluated in the Malmö Diet and Cancer study, Sweden, where significant associations for PA were shown with anthropometric and metabolic variables. 18

sec.title: Assessment of MetS According to the NCEP
sec.p: For the diagnosis of MetS, NCEP requires that at least 3 of 5 clinical criteria are present:

(1) fasting plasma glucose ≥6.1 mmol/L (≥100 mg/dL); (2) BP ≥130/85 mm Hg (either value) or current antihypertensive medication; (3) triglyceride levels ≥1.7 mmol/L (≥150 mg/dL); (4) HDL-C levels <1.0 mmol/L (<40 mg/dL); and (5) waist circumference >88 cm. 9

sec.title: Statistics
sec.p: All statistics were performed using SPSS 17.0 for Windows. Results are presented as mean ± SD unless otherwise indicated. A t test was used to compare continuous data. Comparison of nominal data was performed using Pearson chi-square test. The sedentary activity group was used as reference in the analyses. A P value of <.05 (2-sided) was regarded significant. Cigarette years are presented as median and range.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: In this group of 64-year-old women with IGT (n = 207), 50% was diagnosed as having the MetS according to the NCEP criteria. 9 Anthropometric and metabolic characteristics are summarized in Table 1 . Body weight, body mass index (BMI), waist circumference, and waist–hip ratio were significantly increased in the individuals with MetS. In individuals with the MetS, the diastolic BP was significantly increased compared with those without MetS. Further, individuals with the MetS showed a dyslipidemic pattern with increased triglyceride levels and decreased HDL-C levels. Both glucose and insulin levels differed significantly between the groups, where the highest values were observed in the group with MetS. Further, individuals with the MetS showed increased levels of C-reactive protein (CRP) compared with individuals without MetS.

sec.title: Physical Activity and the MetS
sec.p: Figure 1 shows a significant trend (P < .05) toward fewer individuals with MetS by increased LTPA. Metabolic syndrome was more common in the group that spends their leisure time with sedentary activities and was less common in the group that performed hard/competitive PAs during their leisure time.

caption.p: Bar chart illustrating the distribution of the metabolic syndrome (MetS) according to the National Cholesterol Education Program (NCEP) criteria in the leisure-time physical activity (LTPA) groups (n = 207). Linear to linear association P < .05, Pearson chi-square.

sec.p: A significant difference (P < .05) in prevalence of MetS was observed between the groups who enjoyed a sedentary lifestyle compared to the group that performed regular/competitive levels of LTPA.
A significant negative correlation between LTPA and waist circumference and triglycerides (r s = −0.157, P = .027 and r s = −0.159, P = .026) was observed.

sec.title: Prevalence of the Single Parameter Contained in the MetS
sec.p: Increased BP (93%) presented the highest prevalence followed by increased waist circumference (61%) and increased triglyceride levels (35%).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This cross-sectional study of 64-year-old women with IGT living in the Gothenburg region showed a high prevalence of MetS when using the NCEP criteria. 8 An inverse association between LTPA and MetS was observed, with higher prevalence of MetS in the sedentary group and lowest prevalence in the group that performed hard/competitive PA during their leisure time.

In a population-based study by Halldin et al, a similar association between PA and MetS was observed in 60-year-old participants. They included both sexes, but the study was not restricted to participants with IGT—a high-risk population. 2 Our study showed that 83% of the women with IGT performed at least light PAs during their leisure time. This is in accordance with the study by Halldin and coworkers in which 72% to 83% of the participants reported a light-to-moderate PA. 2 They also observed that the 3 most prevalent MetS components were BP, and waist circumference together with increased triglyceride levels. This is in accordance with our present study as well as what we have earlier reported from 58-year-old men in the in the Atherosclerosis and Insulin Resistance study (AIR) study. 19

In the present study, we observed that waist circumference, a recognized marker for visceral fat, was significantly higher in the MetS group. This is important, given the impact of visceral fat on the typical dyslipidemic pattern seen in the MetS, with elevated triglyceride levels and decreased levels of HDL-C. 20 Further, individuals with MetS are characterized by upper body obesity which in turn, is associated with increased CRP levels. This association is suggested to depend on the synthesis of tumor necrosis factor-α (TNF-α), interleukin 6 (IL-6), and leptin from the adipose tissue. 21,22 Increased CRP levels in MetS have been previously observed in the West of Scotland Coronary Prevention Study (WOSCOPS) study 23 and were associated with a higher cardiovascular risk. C-reactive protein has also emerged as an independent risk factor in a large prospective study of clinically healthy women with or without MetS.

There are methodological aspects to this study which have to be considered. First, we used the NCEP criteria for assessing the prevalence of MetS. However, the prevalence of MetS differs significantly according to which definition is used. 24

Second, the questionnaire used in this study relies on self-reported LTPA. However, there is no gold-standard method to assess LTPA. The format of the questionnaire used in our study has previously been demonstrated to show significant associations with both anthropometric factors and metabolic components. 18

Third, this study had a cross-sectional design and we cannot draw any conclusions about causality. However, the advantage of a cross-sectional design is that the all variables are assessed at the same time and therefore bias owing to variations between independent and dependent variables within the same individual is reduced.

Moreover, we have focused on a cohort of IGT women with the weakness that the results cannot be extended beyond the studied cohort. Nevertheless, focusing on a single cohort has the advantage that it rules out variation in age, sex, and ethnicity. Further, IGT is a clinically silent but important risk factor for type 2 diabetes. We only included women, and diabetes in women is associated with a higher relative risk of cardiovascular disease than for men. 25
Further, the present study was fairly small. Therefore, a larger study will be needed to validate the relationship between LTPA and MetS in patients with IGT and to adjust for covariates.

In conclusion, this study demonstrated a high prevalence of MetS among 64-year-old women with IGT. The occurrence of MetS was less common in the group that performed hard/competitive PA compared with the group that was more sedentary. This study suggests that increased levels of PA have an important role in preventing MetS in women with IGT.
